page.title: 04COASTAL PROTECTION
page.content: The Coastal Protection Act was first instituted in 1949, making the Regional Councils responsible for the unkeep of areas experiencing coastal erosion other than privately owned land by the coast which has to be kept in repair by the person who owns the property. On cliff areas a concrete wall is usually constructed at the base of the cliff, thus preventing the powerful waves from eroding and undercutting the cliffs. These walls must withstand the force of the waves, thus, when they are constructed, they are reinforced by steel bars. Where erosion is more serious, rocks are piled between the wall and the cliffs, giving added protection. The upper part of the cliff can be stabilised by pinning seed-impregnated netting over the softer unconsolidated surface.
